title: 114_s2613
content: The "Adam Walsh Reauthorization Act of 2016" authorizes $20,000,000 for the Sex Offender Management Assistance (SOMA) program for fiscal years 2017 through 2018. This Act also reauthorizes federal assistance for violations of registration requirements. The Adam Walsh Child Protection and Safety Act of 2006 is amended to allocate $61,300,000 to the United States Marshals Service for fiscal years 2017 through 2018. Additionally, provisions are made to ensure supervision of released sexually dangerous persons and to enhance sexual assault survivors' rights in the United States Code. Sexual assault survivors have rights including not being charged for medical exams and having evidence preserved for up to 20 years. Sexual assault survivors have the right to access information from their sexual assault evidence collection kit, including toxicology reports, without impeding an ongoing investigation. They also have the right to be informed of policies regarding the collection and preservation of the kit. Additionally, survivors have the right to receive written notification before the destruction or disposal of the kit and its contents, and can request further information if needed. Sexual assault survivors have the right to access information from their sexual assault evidence collection kit, including toxicology reports, without impeding an ongoing investigation. They also have the right to be informed of policies regarding the collection and preservation of the kit. Survivors can request further preservation of the kit or its contents and must be informed of their rights under this section. The definition of sexual assault includes any nonconsensual sexual act under Federal, tribal, or State law. Funding for this section is specified under the Victims of Crime Act of 1984. Technical and Conforming Amendment: The table of chapters for part II of title 18, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following. Section 1402(d)(3)(A)(i) of the Victims of Crime Act of 1984 is amended to include section 3772 for direct services. Additionally, a new section 1404F is added for Sexual Assault Survivors' Notification Grants. The Attorney General may grant funds to States for developing and distributing written notices of rights and policies for sexual assault survivors. Recipients of the grant must ensure entities provide survivors with information on rights such as no fees for sexual assault evidence collection kits and the right to a medical forensic examination regardless of law enforcement involvement. The grant recipients must disseminate written notices to various entities regarding rights and policies for sexual assault survivors, including access to sexual assault advocates, protective orders, evidence collection kit storage policies, preservation requests, and victim compensation. The Attorney General may provide technical assistance to help recipients comply with the requirements of disseminating written notices to entities serving sexual assault survivors. Any system developed under this section can be integrated with an existing case management system if it meets the specified requirements. SEC. 7. WORKING GROUP. The Attorney General and the Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish a Working Group to develop best practices for the care of sexual assault survivors and preservation of forensic evidence. The Working Group will consult with various stakeholders in law enforcement, prosecution, counseling, and medical fields, as well as experts in sexual assault prevention and advocacy. The Working Group, established by the Attorney General and the Secretary of Health and Human Services, will include representatives, develop recommendations for improving coordination of best practices for the care and treatment of sexual assault survivors, and encourage adoption of these practices among hospital administrators. The Working Group, established by the Attorney General and the Secretary of Health and Human Services, aims to promote coordination of best practices for the care and treatment of sexual assault survivors and the preservation of evidence among medical and law enforcement leaders. They also plan to develop incentives to encourage the adoption of these best practices. The Working Group, comprised of key law enforcement and forensic science leaders, aims to gather feedback from various stakeholders to develop best practices for the care of sexual assault survivors. They will also engage in activities to advance victim-centered care and submit a report to the Attorney General within 2 years. The Working Group, comprised of law enforcement and forensic science leaders, will submit a report to the Attorney General, Secretary, and Congress with findings and recommended actions. SEC. 8. Civil remedy for survivors of child sexual exploitation and human trafficking. Amends Section 2255(b) of title 18, United States Code by extending the time limit to 10 years. Passed the Senate on May 23, 2016.
